title: Allocation of slots at European Union airports: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on common rules for the allocation of slots at EU airports (recast)
background: The European Commission proposed recasting EU airport slot allocation rules in 2011 amid rising air traffic demand and constrained airport capacity, aiming to optimize infrastructure use. The Parliament will discuss regulatory reforms to establish common slot allocation rules, balancing operational efficiency, competition, and connectivity across EU airports.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA firmly supports the issue's procedural integrity in codifying existing legislation without dilution of environmental safeguards, perfectly aligning with their constitutional commitment to legislative transparency.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the issue's implicit rejection of ground handling liberalization that risks social dumping, upholding their manifesto pledge to protect airport workers' rights.  
The issue effectively advances GREEN_EFA's priority of local autonomy in noise management by maintaining current restrictions against economic interference, safeguarding communities from harmful nighttime operations.  
GREEN_EFA firmly supports the rejection of Commission overreach in regional flight curfews, reinforcing their decades-long advocacy for binding WHO noise standards over corporate interests.  
This legislative consolidation perfectly aligns with GREEN_EFA's systemic critique of aviation subsidies by preserving existing frameworks until full sectoral taxation parity is achieved.

ECR rejects the slot allocation proposal's failure to substantively advance market liberalization, absolutely againsting with their core principle of open competition.  
ECR opposes the issue's preservation of existing slot rules as inconsistent with their demand for evidence-based reforms to airport capacity constraints.  
ECR absolutely againsts with the noise regulation's shift to EU-level prescriptiveness, directly contradicting their subsidiarity stance on local governance of airport impacts.  
ECR opposes the mandatory rehiring clauses in groundhandling provisions, viewing them as anti-competitive market distortions incompatible with free enterprise principles.  
ECR rejects the proposal's static approach to slot trading proceeds distribution, which disregards their position on market-driven allocation of aviation assets.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the adoption of its position at first reading on the Commission’s proposal to codify existing legislation without introducing substantive changes, as confirmed by the Consultative Working Party of the legal services, which concluded the proposal merely consolidated prior acts and amendments without altering their substance. The resolution emphasized adherence to the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (Articles 294(2) and 100(2)) and called on the Commission to resubmit the proposal to Parliament if substantial revisions or replacements were planned. It instructed the President to communicate Parliament’s position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, ensuring transparency and procedural continuity in the legislative process.

title: Alternative fuels infrastructure: REPORT on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the deployment of alternative fuels infrastructure
background: The European Union faced high transport sector reliance on imported oil, significant greenhouse gas emissions, and energy security challenges, prompting initiatives to diversify energy sources and reduce environmental impact. The Parliament will discuss regulatory measures to develop infrastructure supporting alternative fuels adoption across member states.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA firmly agrees the technical harmonization provisions for charging infrastructure as foundational to achieving seamless EU-wide electric mobility integration.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the issue's emphasis on binding national infrastructure targets while advocating for future revisions to incorporate renewable energy sourcing requirements.  
GREEN_EFA highlights enhancement opportunities to explicitly tie infrastructure deployment timelines to sectoral decarbonization benchmarks in subsequent implementation phases.  
GREEN_EFA commends the mandatory interoperability standards as effectively advancing consumer confidence in low-emission transport systems.  
GREEN_EFA urges post-adoption monitoring to address the current omission of public transport synergies, ensuring coherence with climate neutrality goals.

GUE_NGL supports the issue’s decarbonization aims while advising explicit differentiation between true zero-emission solutions (renewable electricity/hydrogen) and transitional fuels like methane-based natural gas.  
GUE_NGL urges amending Article 4 to mandate binding lifecycle emission thresholds for any infrastructure labeled "alternative," excluding fossil-derived natural gas from long-term incentives.  
GUE_NGL emphasizes accelerating hydrogen standardization efforts, proposing a 2025 deadline for EU-wide compatibility protocols for refueling stations.  
GUE_NGL advises revising Directive terminology to classify electricity as an "energy carrier" rather than a fuel, ensuring scientific coherence in policy frameworks.  
GUE_NGL calls for reallocating 30% of natural gas infrastructure funds to hydrogen R&D and rural EV charging networks to prioritize genuinely sustainable systems.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s transport-related proposal (COM(2013)0018), grounded in Treaty Articles 294(2), 91, and 294(3), while incorporating input from the European Economic and Social Committee, the Committee of the Regions, and parliamentary committees on Transport and Tourism (report A7-0444/2013) and Industry, Research, and Energy. It formally adopted its first-reading stance, emphasizing the need for the Commission to resubmit the proposal to Parliament if intending significant amendments or replacement, and directed its President to transmit the adopted position to the EU Council, Commission, and national parliaments to ensure procedural continuity and institutional alignment.

title: European Maritime Safety Agency: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 1406/2002 establishing a European Maritime Safety Agency
background: Major offshore oil spills, including the 2010 Deepwater Horizon disaster and 2011 Gannet Alpha leak, highlighted risks to marine environments from oil and gas operations. Existing EU maritime safety frameworks focused on vessel-related pollution, while EMSA's mandate centered on ship safety and pollution response. The Parliament will discuss expanding EMSA's regulatory scope to address offshore installation safety and cross-border maritime challenges.

stances.stance:
ALDE strongly promotes the enhanced coordination of maritime safety resources through EMSA’s expanded mandate, aligning perfectly with ALDE’s longstanding commitment to efficient, supranational solutions for transboundary environmental and security challenges.  
ALDE applauds the integration of satellite monitoring for anti-piracy operations, which effectively advances ALDE’s priority of leveraging innovation to strengthen maritime security and crisis response capabilities.  
ALDE proposes reinforcing regional actors’ inclusion in future disaster response frameworks, noting their proven effectiveness during incidents like the Prestige spill, to ensure localized expertise complements EU-level coordination.  
ALDE urges amendments to incorporate gender balance in EMSA’s governance structures, aligning with broader EU equality goals while maintaining strong backing for the agency’s operational modernization.  
ALDE endorses cross-border cooperation with Norway and Iceland, emphasizing that EMSA’s expanded assistance to neighboring states reflects shared maritime safety imperatives beyond EU borders.

ECR fundamentally disputes the expansion of EMSA's mandate into inland waterways and offshore installations, viewing it as unnecessary duplication of existing national and international efforts.  
ECR rejects the creation of a European coastguard service, asserting that national coastguards already cooperate effectively and additional EU structures are redundant.  
ECR highlights that extending EMSA's competencies to oil/gas platform inspections contradicts the principle of subsidiarity, as member states already maintain rigorous monitoring systems.  
ECR criticizes the proposal's failure to address budgetary impacts, particularly during economic challenges, deeming expanded mandates unjustified without clear cost-benefit analysis.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the application of point 47 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 17 May 2006 on budgetary discipline and sound financial management to the extension of tasks of the European Maritime Safety Agency (EMSA), emphasizing that such extensions must not preempt decisions by the budgetary authority during annual budget procedures. It adopted its first-reading position on the Commission’s 2010 proposal (COM(2010)0611) and stressed the need for the Commission to re-engage Parliament if intending to substantially amend or replace the proposal, ensuring continued legislative oversight. The resolution underscored adherence to Treaty provisions (Article 100(2) TFEU) and procedural frameworks while prioritizing budgetary neutrality and institutional accountability in expanding EMSA’s mandate.

title: European statistics on tourism: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council concerning European Statistics on tourism
background: The European Union's tourism sector, contributing 5% to GDP, operated under a 1995 statistical framework outdated by global competition, digital booking trends, and new Treaty of Lisbon competences. The Parliament will discuss modernizing regulations for harmonized tourism statistics to address evolving industry dynamics and inform policy development.

stances.stance:
EPP completely accepts the updated tourism statistics framework as perfectly aligning with its commitment to data-driven economic growth, particularly through inclusion of same-day visit metrics and tourist expenditure tracking.  
EPP perfectly supports the issue’s focus on accessibility data for reduced mobility, reflecting its longstanding prioritization of inclusive social policies within market modernization.  
EPP unequivocally backs the harmonized statistical methodology, recognizing its critical role in maintaining Europe’s global tourism leadership through comparable cross-border insights.  
EPP endorses the delegated act provisions as a balanced mechanism to ensure legislative agility while preserving parliamentary oversight, consistent with its transparency principles.  
EPP affirms the regulation’s strategic synergy with EU tourism competitiveness goals, particularly in enabling targeted regional development through granular expenditure and mobility analytics.

SD completely advocates the regulation's mandate for harmonized tourism statistics, particularly the inclusion of social tourism metrics, which aligns perfectly with SD's commitment to addressing social equity and regional development through accessible travel opportunities.  
SD perfectly aligns with the issue's expansion of statistical criteria to encompass environmental impact assessments and accessibility standards, advancing sustainable tourism practices as outlined in SD's 2020 policy agenda.  
SD highlights the regulation's potential to standardize workforce data collection, including seasonal employment and training qualifications, which directly supports SD's advocacy for quality job creation in SMEs.  
SD applauds the integration of tourism satellite accounts into EU statistical frameworks, a move that effectively advances evidence-based policymaking for one of Europe's most critical economic sectors.  
SD underscores the issue’s focus on EU funding transparency in tourism sectors, reinforcing SD’s longstanding priority of aligning public expenditure with social and economic cohesion goals.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position at first reading on the Commission’s transport and tourism proposal (COM(2010)0117), grounded in the Committee on Transport and Tourism’s report (A7‑0329/2010), to formalize its stance under relevant Treaty provisions. It urged the Commission to resubmit the proposal to Parliament if substantial amendments or a replacement text are planned, ensuring legislative transparency and procedural adherence. The Parliament further directed its President to transmit its adopted position to the Council, the Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing inter-institutional communication and alignment. The resolution emphasized procedural continuity while focusing on the substantive handling of the proposal, omitting specific voting or amendment details.

title: European transport-technology strategy for Europe's future sustainable mobility: REPORT on promoting a European transport-technology strategy for Europe’s future sustainable mobility
background: The EU has established transport sustainability goals through the Europe 2020 strategy, Horizon 2020 framework, and 2011 White Paper, aiming to reduce emissions, improve energy efficiency, and enhance safety amid persistent environmental, infrastructural, and innovation challenges. The Parliament will discuss a coordinated transport-technology strategy to advance sustainable mobility and cross-regional connectivity.

stances.stance:
SD strongly approves the issue’s focus on reducing regional disparities through cross-border infrastructure and intermodality, aligning perfectly with S&D’s commitment to territorial cohesion and inclusive growth.  
SD approves the establishment of a transport R&I monitoring system, proposing that regional decision-makers receive free, real-time data to enhance EU fund accessibility and reduce implementation delays.  
SD applauds the prioritization of disadvantaged regions, such as islands and remote areas, which directly advances S&D’s goals of equitable resource distribution and social justice in mobility policies.  
SD highlights the necessity of integrating labor mobility into sustainable transport planning, reinforcing economic integration and strengthening cross-border workforce collaboration.  
SD emphasizes the importance of simplifying funding mechanisms for SMEs, a cornerstone of S&D’s advocacy for innovation-driven, grassroots economic development.

GUE_NGL strongly endorses the issue's emphasis on sustainable mobility systems and intelligent transport solutions, aligning with their commitment to ecological transition and public service principles.  
GUE_NGL proposes strengthening Article 14 to explicitly safeguard public transport funding against austerity measures, citing Portugal’s 20% usage decline as a cautionary example requiring preventive clauses.  
GUE_NGL applauds the focus on intermodality and zero-emission technologies as critical to advancing climate justice, matching their manifesto priorities for decarbonized public infrastructure.  
GUE_NGL highlights the need to amend Paragraph 32 to mandate affordability benchmarks for public transport pricing, ensuring accessibility aligns with the issue’s inclusivity goals.  
GUE_NGL urges integrating enforceable anti-privatization safeguards in cross-border infrastructure projects to prevent service fragmentation contradicting sustainability targets.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the critical need for a European transport-technology strategy to achieve sustainable, safe, and resource-efficient mobility, aligning with EU 2020 targets, including 20% reductions in greenhouse gas emissions, renewable energy share, and energy efficiency by 2020, alongside halving road deaths compared to 2001 levels. It emphasized prioritizing research and innovation (R&I) to address environmental challenges, reduce traffic noise, air pollutants, and energy consumption, and enhance road safety, noting over 31,000 fatalities and 1.5 million injuries in EU road accidents in 2012. The resolution called for adequate funding of Horizon 2020, support for SMEs through simplified funding access, and technology-neutral policies to avoid market distortions, while promoting intermodality, cross-border infrastructure, and regional inclusivity, particularly for disadvantaged areas like islands and remote regions. It advocated for intelligent transport systems (ITS), zero-emission maritime technologies, sustainable urban mobility plans, and incentives for cycling, walking, and public transport. The Parliament stressed integrating user perspectives via tools like TRIMIS, harmonizing vehicle standards, and internalizing transport costs through "polluter pays" principles. It urged EU institutions to lead by example in sustainable mobility management and highlighted the role of regional authorities in deploying innovation, smart specialization, and EU funds to bridge infrastructure gaps and foster territorial cohesion.

title: External aviation policy: REPORT on the EU’s External Aviation Policy – Addressing future challenges
background: The EU’s external aviation policy, established in 2005, faced evolving global competition, job losses in European airlines, delays in Single European Sky implementation, and emerging market growth in Asia and the Middle East. The Parliament will discuss strengthening the policy to address market access, fair competition, and regulatory alignment with international partners.

stances.stance:
ALDE strongly promotes the issue's emphasis on fair competition clauses in aviation agreements, aligning perfectly with ALDE's commitment to addressing market distortions caused by state-subsidized carriers like Emirates.  
ALDE approves the push for comprehensive agreements with Gulf states and key global markets, effectively advancing ALDE's priority of reciprocal market access and economic integration.  
ALDE urges binding implementation timelines for the Single European Sky, proposing enhanced technical coordination to eliminate inefficient flight paths and achieve the ecological benefits outlined in ALDE's sustainability agenda.  
ALDE highlights the necessity of regulatory alignment in international negotiations, strongly promoteing measures to protect European airlines' competitiveness through harmonized standards and fair taxation.  
ALDE emphasizes accelerating infrastructure modernization to reduce congestion, endorsing the issue's focus on regional connectivity as critical to ALDE's growth-oriented policies.

SD totally accepts the issue’s prioritization of comprehensive aviation agreements with strategic partners like Ukraine and Tunisia, perfectly aligning with SD’s vision for expanding EU market access and regional connectivity.  
SD perfectly aligns with the issue’s demand for fair competition clauses to counter non-EU carriers’ state subsidies, reflecting SD’s longstanding advocacy against market-distorting practices.  
SD totally accepts the urgency of concluding agreements with Turkey, Armenia, and Libya, emphasizing the issue’s call for proactive diplomacy to unlock economic opportunities.  
SD highlights the issue’s alignment with SD’s commitment to job creation, particularly through replicating the success of the EU-US agreement that generated 80,000 jobs.  
SD emphasizes the issue’s critical focus on addressing Gulf carriers’ unfair advantages as an enhancement opportunity to solidify global competitiveness, mirroring SD’s anti-subsidy campaigns.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the importance of a cohesive EU external aviation policy to enhance global competitiveness, economic growth, and employment, noting the sector supports over 5 million jobs and contributes 2.4% to EU GDP. It highlighted progress in initiatives like the Single European Sky (SES), SESAR, and EU-US Air Transport Agreement, which created 80,000 jobs, but expressed concern over SES delays and urged punitive measures against non-compliant Member States. The resolution stressed challenges from non-EU carriers benefiting from subsidies, unfair practices, and infrastructure investments in Asia, the Middle East, and South America, while calling for fair competition clauses in agreements and reciprocity in market access. It emphasized the need to address disparities in taxes, airport charges, and social standards, particularly criticizing low-cost carriers for undermining labor rights despite holding 40% of the EU market. The Parliament urged concluding comprehensive agreements with Brazil, Australia, China, India, and Gulf states, addressing Russian overflight fees violating international law, and strengthening ICAO’s role in global emissions and safety standards. It advocated for regulatory alignment, consumer rights, and social impact assessments in aviation negotiations, while promoting regional airports and infrastructure investments to alleviate congestion and boost connectivity. The resolution also called for revised trade defense instruments, transparency in Gulf state negotiations, and enforcement of ILO labor standards to protect workers amid market liberalization.

title: Aerodromes, air traffic management and air navigation services: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 216/2008 in the field of aerodromes, air traffic management and air navigation services
background: Fragmented European airspace management caused inefficiencies, delays, higher operational costs compared to global counterparts, and environmental concerns due to suboptimal flight routes. Existing Single European Sky regulations (SES I/II) faced implementation challenges in harmonising national systems. The Parliament will discuss regulatory amendments to enhance air traffic efficiency, safety standards, and operational integration across member states.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the issue’s emphasis on cross-border airspace cooperation, recognizing its critical role in reducing emissions through optimized flight routes.  
GREEN_EFA fundamentally sanctions the rejection of rigid service separation mandates, affirming that context-specific governance models better serve both efficiency and sovereignty concerns.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the need to enhance democratic scrutiny of delegated acts, proposing strengthened parliamentary oversight mechanisms to prevent regulatory overreach.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the issue’s alignment with functional airspace block progress, particularly its indirect support for reducing military airspace restrictions as a climate mitigation measure.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes that the issue’s procedural rigor under Article 100(2) TFEU advances their vision of EU-wide ecological standardization in aviation governance.

GUE/NGL rejects the proposal as fully disputeing with their opposition to ultraliberal aviation policies that prioritize corporate interests over public safety and workers' rights.  
GUE/NGL opposes the dismantling of national air traffic control structures, which would privatize critical services and risk safety through underpaid, precarious labor conditions.  
GUE/NGL condemns the market-driven approach to airspace management as incompatible with their commitment to public ownership and sovereignty over strategic transport infrastructure.  
GUE/NGL highlights the proposal’s failure to address safety risks from fragmented navigation services, directly contradicting their demand for rigorous aviation safety standards.  
GUE/NGL rejects the issue’s alignment with airline industry deregulation, which threatens thousands of jobs in peripheral EU states and undermines environmental sustainability goals.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2013 legislative proposal (COM(2013)0409) concerning transport and tourism policy, while addressing a subsidiarity objection from the Maltese House of Representatives. The resolution adopted Parliament’s first-reading stance, urged the Commission to re-engage Parliament if proposing significant amendments, and mandated the transmission of its position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments. It incorporated input from the Committee on Transport and Tourism’s report and acknowledged the European Economic and Social Committee’s 2013 opinion, emphasizing procedural adherence to Treaty obligations under Article 100(2) TFEU.

title: Electronic toll service and vignette system on light private vehicles: REPORT on a strategy for an electronic toll service and a vignette system on light private vehicles in Europe
background: Persistent challenges in achieving interoperability among national electronic toll systems, declining fuel tax revenues, and fragmented road charging approaches across EU Member States prompted calls for coordinated infrastructure funding solutions. The Parliament will discuss strategies to implement a harmonized electronic toll service and vignette system for light private vehicles across Europe.

stances.stance:
EFD rejects the issue's reliance on satellite-based toll systems as completely condemning with EFD's principle of protecting citizens' privacy rights against state surveillance.  
EFD opposes the prioritization of distance-based tolling for private vehicles, highlighting its inconsistency with EFD's demand for phased implementation starting exclusively with freight transport.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects such as public acceptance of personal movement tracking, which EFD considers a red line for individual liberty protections.  
EFD condemns the issue's enforcement mechanisms as disproportionate state interference, contradicting subsidiarity principles central to EFD's platform.  
This approach fails to address EFD's core concern that mandatory EU-wide electronic tolling creates irreversible infrastructure for mass vehicular monitoring.

SD strongly upholds the enforcement of legislative measures to eliminate member state inertia, aligning perfectly with SD’s commitment to fair cross-border mobility and infrastructure equity.  
SD endorses the issue’s prioritization of distance-based tolling over vignettes, effectively advancing SD’s principle of non-discrimination against non-resident drivers and border communities.  
SD applauds the mandate for interoperable GPS/GNSS systems and simplified mobile payments, which aligns with SD’s digital innovation agenda for seamless EU-wide services.  
SD emphasizes the urgency of ring-fencing toll revenues for sustainable transport infrastructure, consistent with SD’s climate neutrality goals and Just Transition priorities.  
SD proposes amending Article 4 to include biannual Commission implementation reviews, enhancing accountability while fully supporting the issue’s 2013 deadline for interoperability studies.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over the failure of the European Electronic Toll Service (EETS) to achieve interoperability, citing insufficient stakeholder incentives, lack of political will, and the inadequacy of a market-driven approach. It urged the Commission to enforce legislative measures, including sanctions for non-compliant Member States, and to propose an incentive scheme to accelerate EETS implementation, emphasizing the need for interoperability using existing technologies like GPS/GNSS while ensuring compliance with EU data protection rules. The resolution stressed prioritizing distance-based tolling over time-based vignettes to ensure fairness and non-discrimination, particularly for non-residents and border regions, and called for simplified, transparent payment systems, including mobile and online options, with vignettes purchasable up to 30 days in advance. It highlighted the urgency of coordinated action as more Member States plan road charges for light vehicles, advocating ring-fenced revenues for sustainable infrastructure and opposing extra charges on SMEs and haulage companies. The Parliament demanded a Commission review of interoperability studies by end-2013, infrastructure signage improvements, and infringement proceedings for discriminatory toll systems, while affirming Member States’ rights to set charges but urging alignment with EU-wide goals to prevent fragmentation and uphold free movement principles.

title: Community guidelines for the development of the trans-European transport network (recast): REPORT on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on Community guidelines for the development of the trans-European transport network (recast)
background: The European Commission proposed recasting the Trans-European Transport Network (TEN-T) guidelines to consolidate prior amendments and address technical inaccuracies following the 2004 EU enlargement, which expanded the network’s geographic scope. The Parliament will discuss updating the TEN-T framework to align with institutional reforms and integrate new Member States’ infrastructure.

stances.stance:
EFD supports the codification of transport network guidelines while advising explicit recognition of eastern connectivity projects like the Čierna nad Tisou-Vienna broad-gauge railway extension.  
EFD proposes amending Annex II to prioritize transcontinental rail links aligning with Asian trade growth, ensuring future funding mechanisms accommodate such strategic corridors.  
EFD highlights the economic imperative of integrating Danube ports with eastern rail routes, urging procedural transparency clauses to include cross-border infrastructure consultations.  
EFD advises strengthening Resolution Clause 7 to mandate periodic reviews of eastward network expansions, reflecting evolving trade dynamics with China and India.  
EFD underscores the need for coherence between EU infrastructure planning and global supply chain demands, suggesting non-binding recitals reference Eurasian connectivity opportunities.

SD completely advocates the codification process as perfectly aligning with their commitment to procedural transparency and legislative stability in trans-European infrastructure planning.  
SD perfectly supports the issue’s institutional cooperation framework, emphasizing its role in advancing integrated transport corridors like the Pyrenees low-level tunnel and Mediterranean linkages.  
SD highlights the necessity of maintaining existing TEN-T guidelines to ensure calculability for Member States, while preparing for future expansions such as Black Sea maritime routes and Ukraine-Moldova road connections.  
SD underscores the urgency of developing high-speed rail networks and inland waterways, framing these priorities as natural extensions of the issue’s unchanged provisions.  
SD stresses the critical alignment between the issue’s procedural safeguards and timely Commission communications on methodology, ensuring cohesion in upcoming network revisions.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on a Commission proposal concerning the codification of existing legal texts without substantive changes, as confirmed by the Consultative Working Party of the legal services of the EU institutions, which concluded the proposal merely consolidated earlier acts without altering their substance. The resolution endorsed the codification process, emphasizing adherence to procedural transparency and institutional cooperation, and called on the Commission to resubmit the matter to Parliament if it substantially amends or replaces the proposal. It further instructed the Parliament’s President to formally communicate its adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, ensuring alignment with the Treaty on the Functioning of the EU and maintaining legislative coherence across unchanged provisions.

title: Compensation and assistance to passengers in the event of denied boarding and of cancellation or long delay of flights: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 261/2004 establishing common rules on compensation and assistance to passengers in the event of denied boarding and of cancellation or long delay of flights and Regulation (EC) No 2027/97 on air carrier liability in respect of the carriage of passengers and their baggage by air
background: Persistent inconsistencies in applying EU air passenger rights regulations, including varied enforcement, ambiguous exemptions for extraordinary circumstances, and operational disruptions affecting compensation claims, prompted legal challenges and calls for clarity. The Parliament will discuss amending rules on compensation and assistance for denied boarding, cancellations, or delays to address enforcement gaps and passenger protection.

stances.stance:
SD strongly upholds the strict limitation of "extraordinary circumstances" definitions to prevent airline abuse of technical issues, aligning perfectly with SD's consumer protection priorities.  
SD applauds the introduction of delay compensation rights as critical progress in passenger justice, effectively advancing SD's manifesto commitment to traveler dignity.  
SD endorses enhanced transparency through mandatory all-inclusive pricing displays and airport assistance points, matching SD's decade-long push against hidden fees.  
SD proposes strengthening accessibility provisions by requiring immediate wheelchair/special equipment return post-flight to fully uphold disabled passengers' rights.  
SD emphasizes the issue's alignment with SD's transport equity agenda through binding airline liability for cancellations and simplified claims procedures.

ECR entirely condemns the issue's exclusion of Gibraltar from passenger rights protections, conflicting with their principle of equal treatment for all EU citizens.  
ECR rejects the regulation’s failure to prohibit airlines from denying return flights due to unused outbound segments, contradicting fair contractual obligations.  
ECR opposes the ambiguous definition of "extraordinary circumstances," which inadequately excludes technical maintenance failures despite carriers’ operational responsibilities.  
ECR rejects the proposal’s potential to increase airfare costs through excessive consumer safeguards, inconsistent with market efficiency priorities.  
ECR entirely condemns the lack of explicit requirements for passenger disembarkation during prolonged tarmac delays, disregarding basic dignity protections.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2013 proposal (COM(2013)0130) concerning transport-related regulations under Treaty Articles 294(2) and 100(2), informed by the Committee on Transport and Tourism’s report (A7-0020/2014) and the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection’s opinion. It adopted its first-reading stance, emphasizing the need for alignment with internal market and consumer protection principles, and urged the Commission to re-engage Parliament if proposing substantial amendments to the original text. The resolution further instructed the President to communicate Parliament’s position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, ensuring procedural continuity while prioritizing substantive coherence with EU treaty frameworks and stakeholder consultations, including the European Economic and Social Committee’s 2013 opinion.

title: Aviation security charges: REPORT on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on aviation security charges
background: Following the 2001 establishment of EU-wide aviation security measures, divergent national approaches to financing security costs led to inconsistent charges across member states. The Parliament will discuss a proposed directive to standardize aviation security charge regulations, addressing transparency, non-discrimination, and cost-related fee structures for airport operators and airlines.

stances.stance:
EFD supports the transparency framework for aviation charges but advises amending cost-allocation clauses to strictly limit charges to demonstrably incurred security expenses.  
EFD endorses harmonized EU security standards to prevent market fragmentation while cautioning against redundant oversight bodies that could inflate operational costs.  
EFD emphasizes the need for explicit passenger-facing breakdowns of security charges, aligning with their principle of eliminating "jungle-like" hidden fees.  
EFD approves the issue’s rejection of national surcharges but proposes a compliance mechanism to audit operators’ cost claims against actual security investments.  
EFD concurs with preventing profit-driven exploitation of security mandates but suggests sunset clauses for fee structures to ensure ongoing cost-benefit alignment.

ALDE firmly agrees the issue's mandate for transparent breakdowns of aviation security charges, aligning perfectly with their commitment to consumer rights and fiscal accountability.  
ALDE applauds the directive's requirement that security charges be strictly allocated to actual security measures, preventing misuse of passenger funds.  
ALDE emphasizes the necessity for Member States to finance any security enhancements exceeding EU standards, upholding national responsibility in aviation safety.  
ALDE supports the harmonized approach to charge structures while respecting Member States' operational autonomy, ensuring proportionality in security investments.  
ALDE recognizes the issue as a critical advancement in clarifying passenger cost obligations, reinforcing trust in EU aviation governance frameworks.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on a legislative proposal concerning transport policy, adopting its first reading stance under the Treaty on the Functioning of the EU (Article 100(2)) and emphasizing procedural alignment with the post-Lisbon Treaty framework. It endorsed the Commission’s original proposal (COM(2009)0217) while urging the Commission to resubmit the matter to Parliament if substantial amendments or a replacement text were planned, ensuring continued interinstitutional coherence. The resolution reflected input from the European Economic and Social Committee’s November 2009 opinion and was informed by the Committee on Transport and Tourism’s report (A7‑0035/2010). Parliament instructed its President to formally transmit its adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing transparency and adherence to legislative procedures under the EU’s ordinary legislative process.

title: Deployment of the interoperable EU-wide eCall: REPORT on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the deployment of the interoperable EU-wide eCall
background: Persistent road safety challenges and insufficient voluntary adoption of emergency call technology prompted the European Commission's 2013 proposal for mandatory vehicle-integrated eCall systems using the EU-wide 112 emergency number, requiring cross-border infrastructure coordination. The Parliament will discuss establishing interoperable eCall deployment standards to improve emergency response efficiency and reduce traffic accident fatalities.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA rejects the mandatory eCall system as totally condemning with their principles of proportionality and data protection, emphasizing unresolved tracking risks under Article 5.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the issue's industry-centric approach, highlighting its inconsistency with consumer protection priorities stated in the Internal Market Committee's mandate.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the proposal for diverting funds from proven safety measures like speed limit enforcement, which the Transport Committee failed to prioritize.  
GREEN_EFA challenges the legislative intent's coherence by demonstrating how automated eCall fails to address infrastructure gaps and ambulance response times cited in recital 12.  
GREEN_EFA fundamentally disputes the proportionality justification, noting the issue's omission of hacking vulnerabilities despite Parliament's 2013 cybersecurity directives.

SD strongly agrees the mandatory 112-linked eCall system as a public safety imperative, aligning with their commitment to reduce road fatalities through rapid emergency response while maintaining strict data privacy safeguards.  
SD approves the 2015 deadline for PSAP infrastructure upgrades, urging member states to prioritize technical readiness to ensure seamless pan-EU interoperability as outlined in Articles 4-6.  
SD proposes supplementing the issue with binding awareness campaigns to educate citizens on eCall’s dormant functionality, addressing concerns about low public familiarity raised during committee deliberations.  
SD endorses the prohibition of non-essential data collection, emphasizing that the adopted privacy-by-design approach effectively prevents unauthorized tracking as demanded in their 2014 transport manifesto.  
SD applauds the issue’s cost-benefit alignment, noting projected annual savings of €26 billion through reduced medical and congestion costs directly advance social welfare priorities.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2013 proposal (COM(2013)0315) concerning transport policy, adopting its first-reading stance to advance legislative procedures under Article 91 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the EU. It emphasized the need for the Commission to re-engage Parliament if proposing significant amendments or alternative texts, ensuring alignment with legislative intent. The resolution reflected input from the Committee on Transport and Tourism, alongside opinions from the Committees on Industry, Research and Energy and the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, underscoring cross-sectoral priorities. Parliament instructed its President to formally transmit its adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing procedural transparency and interinstitutional coordination. The resolution aimed to uphold parliamentary oversight while advancing policy coherence in EU transport initiatives.

title: Dimensions and weights of road vehicles circulating within the Community: REPORT on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 96/53/EC of 25 July 1996 laying down for certain road vehicles circulating within the Community the maximum authorised dimensions in national and international traffic and the maximum authorised weights in international traffic
background: The 1996 EU Directive on road vehicle dimensions and weights faced calls for revision due to technological advancements in vehicle design, evolving environmental standards, and divergent national regulations on cross-border transport operations, alongside infrastructure compatibility and road safety concerns raised by member states. The Parliament will discuss updating EU-wide standards for road vehicle dimensions and weights to align with current transport efficiency, environmental, and safety objectives.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA absolutely promotes the issue’s explicit rejection of cross-border Gigaliner expansion, perfectly aligning with their commitment to road safety and infrastructure preservation.

background: Prior EU regulations established passenger rights for air, rail, and maritime transport, but bus/coach services lacked harmonized protections, particularly for disabled persons and cross-border travelers. The sector’s prevalence of small operators and growing demand for accessible transport necessitated standardized rules. The Parliament will discuss EU-wide passenger rights frameworks for bus/coach travel, addressing non-discrimination, compensation, and accessibility.

stances.stance:
ECR strongly agrees the establishment of comprehensive passenger rights in bus and coach transport, completing EU-wide protections across all modes and advancing consumer-focused governance.  
ECR applauds the prioritization of accessibility for disabled passengers and those with special needs, aligning with their commitment to equitable public service provision.  
ECR approves the 250 km exemption protecting local operators from disproportionate burdens, ensuring proportionality and safeguarding SME competitiveness in line with free market principles.  
ECR endorses the exclusion of urban/suburban services from excessive regulation, preventing operational inflexibility and cost escalation for municipal transport systems.  
ECR proposes monitoring mechanisms to verify timely implementation of staff training requirements, enhancing accountability while respecting transitional periods for compliance.

GUE_NGL rejects the regulation's failure to prevent fare hikes that disproportionately burden working-class passengers, contradicting their anti-austerity principles.  
GUE_NGL opposes fundamentally the extended transitional period loophole, which delays critical protections for disabled travelers' wheelchair accessibility rights.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects such as inflation-indexed compensation limits, enabling real-term erosion of passenger financial safeguards.  
GUE_NGL condemns the unresolved insurance ambiguities in Article 4(2) as incompatible with their demand for universal social guarantees.  
This regulation conflicts with GUE_NGL's transport justice agenda by prioritizing insurer profits over binding public service obligations.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the approval of the joint text agreed by the Conciliation Committee (PE-CONS 00063/2010), which resolved differences between its earlier positions and the Council’s stance on the Commission’s 2008 legislative proposal (COM(2008)0817). The resolution incorporated input from the European Economic and Social Committee’s 2009 opinion and aligned with Treaty obligations (Article 294(13) TFEU), finalizing the act for adoption. It mandated the Presidents of Parliament and the Council to sign the act under Article 297(1) TFEU and instructed procedural verification by the Secretaries-General before publication in the Official Journal, concluding the legislative process.

title: Roadworthiness of commercial vehicles: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the technical roadside inspection of the roadworthiness of commercial vehicles circulating in the Union and repealing Directive 2000/30/EC
background: Disparities in commercial vehicle roadworthiness inspections across EU member states under Directive 2000/30/EC, with varying defect detection rates and operational standards, prompted the European Commission to propose updated regulations. The Parliament will discuss harmonizing technical inspection procedures to improve road safety and cross-border consistency while addressing subsidiarity concerns raised by national legislatures.

stances.stance:
EFD partially agrees the issue but demands exemption clauses for non-operational vehicles, as Article 4's penalty regime conflicts with principles of proportionate governance by punishing owners awaiting repairs.  
EFD requests revising Annex II to exclude caravans from inspection requirements, citing decades of accident-free owner maintenance practices that render centralized oversight redundant.  
EFD entirely challenges harmonized roadside inspections (Article 6) for duplicating the UK's MOT system, creating unnecessary costs for hauliers already facing fuel tax burdens.  
EFD highlights the proposal's failure to address enforcement overreach risks under Article 9, which could replicate Slovakia's abusive fine practices against citizens.  
EFD rejects the regulation's assumption of uniform EU standards as inconsistent with national competence over transport safety, urging deletion of Articles 1-3 pending subsidiarity review.

GREEN_EFA firmly supports the mandatory technical inspections for all motorized vehicles including motorcycles, perfectly aligning with their commitment to equitable road safety standards.  
GREEN_EFA strongly upholds the issue’s recognition of motorcycle sophistication, mirroring their advocacy for parity between two-wheeled and four-wheeled vehicle safety protocols.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the inclusion of accident severity reduction measures through technical controls, advancing their priority to protect vulnerable road users.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes the critical importance of adhering to 2016/2018 implementation timelines for motorcycle inspections, reflecting their evidence-based approach to phased safety reforms.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the issue’s grounding in independent studies about technical failures exacerbating accidents, reinforcing their science-driven policymaking ethos.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns regarding the Commission’s 2012 legislative proposal (COM(2012)0382) on transport policy under Article 91 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, while noting objections from the Cypriot Parliament and Dutch legislatures that the proposal violated subsidiarity principles. It adopted its first-reading position based on the Committee on Transport and Tourism’s report (A7-0207/2013) and the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy’s opinion, urging the Commission to resubmit the proposal if substantially amended. The resolution emphasized procedural adherence to Article 294(3) TFEU and Protocol No 2 on subsidiarity, incorporating input from the European Economic and Social Committee and the Committee of the Regions. Parliament instructed its President to transmit its position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, ensuring alignment with legislative processes and institutional consultation requirements.

title: Roadworthiness tests for motor vehicles and their trailers: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on periodic roadworthiness tests for motor vehicles and their trailers and repealing Directive 2009/40/EC
background: The European Commission proposed updated vehicle inspection rules to address divergent national standards and road safety concerns under existing EU transport policies, following evaluations of Directive 2009/40/EC. National parliaments raised subsidiarity objections. The Parliament will discuss harmonizing periodic technical inspections for motor vehicles to improve cross-border safety compliance.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly accepts the harmonization of roadworthiness tests across member states, particularly endorsing uniform cargo security standards and cross-border inspection reciprocity to enhance road safety.  
EPP approves the focus on inspection quality over frequency, aligning with their principle of efficient regulation that respects national operational frameworks while ensuring high safety benchmarks.  
EPP endorses measures to combat odometer fraud through standardized vehicle documentation, emphasizing this as critical for consumer protection in cross-border used vehicle markets.  
EPP proposes enhanced study of motorcycle accident causation data before implementing EU-wide mandatory inspections, citing unresolved statistical discrepancies raised by national experts.  
EPP suggests safeguarding SMEs by maintaining integrated maintenance-and-inspection frameworks, amending Article 12.4 to clarify ISO 17020 application as non-binding for small operators.

GREEN_EFA rejects the exemption of motorcycles from mandatory roadworthiness tests as fundamentally undermining road safety standards.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the issue's failure to align with EU-wide vehicle safety parity, disregarding technical sophistication parity between cars and motorcycles.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the proposal's contradiction with accident prevention goals by ignoring studies showing 5-10% of motorcycle accidents involve technical deficiencies.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the exclusion timeline delays for smaller motorcycles, which exacerbates risks for vulnerable road users.  
GREEN_EFA demands immediate inclusion of all motorized two- and three-wheeled vehicles in testing protocols to prevent preventable fatalities.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns regarding the Commission’s 2012 transport proposal (COM(2012)0380), particularly addressing subsidiarity objections from the French Senate, Netherlands House of Representatives and Senate, Swedish Parliament, and Cypriot House of Representatives, which argued the proposal overstepped EU-level competence. It noted the European Economic and Social Committee’s December 12, 2012, opinion and consulted the Committee of the Regions, while incorporating input from parliamentary committees on Transport and Tourism, Industry, Research and Energy, and the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. The Parliament adopted its first-reading position, urging the Commission to resubmit the proposal if substantial amendments or replacements are planned, and instructed its President to transmit its position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, emphasizing adherence to procedural and consultative frameworks.

title: Single European transport area: REPORT on the Roadmap to a Single European Transport Area – Towards a competitive and resource efficient transport system
background: The EU faced challenges in harmonizing transport systems, including CO₂ emissions growth, infrastructure disparities between eastern/western regions, energy dependency, and fragmented market integration. Previous policies (2001 White Paper, 2020 Strategy) aimed at sustainability and cohesion remained partially unmet. The Parliament will discuss establishing a single European transport area balancing competitiveness, efficiency, and decarbonization.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly agrees the issue’s emission reduction targets and eco-innovation framework, which align perfectly with EPP’s longstanding commitment to sustainable growth and energy diversification.  
EPP approves the harmonized standards for interoperable transport systems but proposes strengthening cross-border coordination on modular road trains to prevent regulatory fragmentation, ensuring unified safety and environmental specifications.  
EPP applauds the accessibility provisions for disabled and elderly passengers as effectively advancing EPP’s priority of inclusive mobility and social cohesion.  
EPP endorses the subsidiarity principle for gigaliner approvals, recognizing regional infrastructure realities while maintaining single market coherence.  
EPP emphasizes the critical need for cohesion-focused infrastructure funding to address disparities, matching EPP’s regional development priorities.

GUE/NGL rejects the issue's market liberalization agenda as completely challengeing with their anti-privatization principles and workers' rights priorities  
GUE/NGL opposes the transport integration model for exacerbating corporate monopolies while failing to address regional disparities in infrastructure development  
GUE/NGL condemns the issue's alignment with IMF-style austerity policies that sacrifice public rail services and island connectivity to privatization schemes  
GUE/NGL highlights the proposal's incompatibility with social cohesion through its promotion of flexible labor practices and erosion of transport safety standards  
GUE/NGL asserts the issue overlooks critical grassroots needs by prioritizing multinational corporate profits over affordable passenger services and SME logistics

resolution: The European Parliament raised the urgent need for a sustainable, efficient, and competitive EU transport sector to meet emission reduction targets, lower energy dependency, and enhance regional integration. It highlighted that transport accounts for over 25% of EU CO2 emissions, stressing the necessity to accelerate emission reductions through eco-innovation, renewable fuels, co-modality, and internalizing external costs across all transport modes. The resolution emphasized achieving a 20% reduction in road transport emissions and a 30% cut in aviation emissions by 2020, alongside promoting electro-mobility, interoperable charging infrastructure, and smart grids. It noted the transport sector’s economic significance, citing 2009 exports of €454.7 billion (41.5% of total EU exports) and trade surpluses of €112.6 billion in machinery and €21.5 billion in services. The Parliament advocated for energy diversification, ICT integration, Intelligent Transport Systems, and modular road trains to boost efficiency, while urging harmonized standards and research into technologies like RFID and Galileo. It called for sustainable biofuels, particularly second-generation, and stressed regional cohesion by addressing infrastructure disparities, prioritizing cross-border projects, and enhancing funding for convergence regions. Urban transport challenges, including congestion and emissions, were addressed through smart city planning and integrated management. The resolution also underscored the potential of short-sea shipping and inland waterways for market integration and disaster resilience, while safeguarding cohesion policy resources.

title: Trans-European transport network: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on Union guidelines for the development of the trans-European transport network
background: The European Commission proposed updated trans-European transport network guidelines to address infrastructure gaps and enhance cross-border connectivity, under Treaty obligations. The French Senate raised subsidiarity concerns, while EU advisory bodies provided opinions. The Parliament will discuss adopting Union guidelines for the trans-European transport network's development.

stances.stance:
EPP completely promotes the multimodal integration framework as perfectly aligning with EPP's longstanding commitment to cohesive European infrastructure development.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the core network prioritization strategy, particularly its inclusion of strategic logistics platforms like Zaragoza and Antequera as critical nodes for Iberian connectivity.  
EPP proposes strengthening financial instruments through enhanced long-term loan mechanisms to complement project bonds, thereby maximizing private sector participation while maintaining full endorsement of the CEF structure.  
EPP urges immediate operationalization of Rail Baltic connectivity enhancements through the issue's corridor provisions, recognizing this as essential for eliminating Baltic regional isolation.  
EPP emphasizes the issue's effective advancement of tourism infrastructure priorities through airport network criteria while suggesting accelerated evaluation for Vigo's port inclusion in core network revisions.

GREEN_EFA rejects the issue's prioritization of delayed megaprojects like Brenner Base Tunnel and Fehmarnbelt Bridge, which contradict sustainable rail development and waste critical funding.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the allocation of resources to redundant highway expansions (e.g., Brno-Austrian border) over restoring WWII-destroyed cross-border rail links essential for European integration.  
GREEN_EFA absolutely challenges with the annexes' inclusion of Lyon-Turin high-speed rail, a fiscally irresponsible project that monopolizes funds while undermining climate-focused infrastructure priorities.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the failure to address systemic underfunding of cross-border rail corridors like Berlin-Swinemünde and Freiburg-Colmar, perpetuating fragmented national networks over a unified European system.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the issue's institutional inertia through projects like the 660-meter Sebnitz-Dolní Poustevna gap, which took 25 years to resolve despite its minimal scale and strategic importance.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2011 legislative proposal (COM(2011)0650/3), grounded in Article 294(2) and Article 172 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, to advance transport infrastructure policies. It acknowledged concerns from the French Senate, which contested the proposal’s compliance with subsidiarity under Protocol No 2, and incorporated opinions from the European Economic and Social Committee (22 February 2012) and the Committee of the Regions (3 May 2012). The resolution formally adopted Parliament’s first-reading stance, urged the Commission to re-engage Parliament if proposing significant amendments or alternative texts, and directed its President to transmit the position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, ensuring procedural continuity while prioritizing legislative coherence and inter-institutional accountability.

title: Charging of heavy goods vehicles for the use of certain infrastructures: REPORT on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 1999/62/EC on the charging of heavy goods vehicles for the use of certain infrastructures
background: The EU’s 1999 infrastructure charging directive for heavy goods vehicles faced calls for reform amid evolving environmental objectives, concerns over competitive distortions between transport modes, and infrastructure financing needs. The Parliament will discuss revising the framework to address emissions, equitable cost distribution, and harmonized road charging mechanisms.

stances.stance:
EFDD partly supports the issue's environmental goals but requests revisions to exempt British livestock producers from CO2-based infrastructure charges until post-Brexit trade agreements are ratified.  
EFDD opposes the uniform phase-out of vignettes by 2024, arguing it firmly againsts with WTO trade fairness principles unless reciprocal standards are enforced on third-country meat imports.  
EFDD demands amendments to Article 7 to require explicit WTO-compliant risk assessments for antibiotic thresholds in animal feed, citing unresolved scientific ambiguities.  
EFDD rejects the issue’s rigid veterinary prescription rules as inconsistent with national sovereignty, proposing instead that member states retain autonomy over livestock medication protocols.  
EFDD highlights that the proposal overlooks critical innovations in antimicrobial resistance, urging reallocation of congestion charge revenues to fund genetic research for disease-resistant poultry.

GREEN_EFA strongly upholds the integration of CO2-based infrastructure charges, aligning perfectly with their commitment to climate accountability and the "polluter pays" principle.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the elimination of vignettes for heavy vehicles by 2024 as a critical step toward reducing emissions from road transport.  
GREEN_EFA endorses the 75% charge reduction for zero-emission vehicles, recognizing its potential to accelerate the transition to sustainable freight systems.  
GREEN_EFA proposes extending congestion charge revenue allocations to explicitly fund low-emission urban mobility projects, enhancing the directive’s environmental impact.  
GREEN_EFA welcomes stringent transparency requirements for toll revenue use, ensuring alignment with their principles of ecological fiscal responsibility.

resolution: The European Parliament raised key measures to reform road charging systems, emphasizing environmental accountability and fair competition. The resolution expands the scope of the directive to include all heavy-duty vehicles (HDVs), including buses and coaches, from 2020, eliminating exemptions for vehicles under 12 tonnes to prevent market distortions. It proposes extending variable infrastructure charges to light vehicles and mandates phasing out vignettes (time-based charges) for HDVs by 2024 and for light vehicles by 2028, prioritizing the "polluter pays" principle. Infrastructure charges for HDVs will vary based on CO2 emissions starting in 2021, while light vehicles will face charges tied to CO2 and EURO emission standards. Zero-emission vehicles will receive a 75% reduction in infrastructure charges. The resolution introduces congestion charges and requires external-cost charges on roads where HDVs cause above-average environmental harm. Additionally, it demands greater transparency in tolling systems and stricter monitoring of revenue use to ensure compliance and accountability.

title: Common rules for access to the international market for coach and bus services: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 1073/2009 on common rules for access to the international market for coach and bus services
background: Existing EU regulations on international coach and bus services, established in 2009, faced evolving market demands and divergent national approaches balancing commercial competition with public service obligations. The Parliament will discuss amending these rules to address cross-border market access and operational standards for international coach and bus services within the EU.

stances.stance:
ALDE strongly endorses the liberalization of long-distance bus services as a strategic tool for decarbonization, emphasizing their capacity to collectively transport citizens while reducing per-passenger carbon footprints.  
ALDE endorses the Spanish concession model for harmonizing market competition with public service obligations, ensuring cross-subsidization between profitable and non-profitable routes to maintain rural accessibility.  
ALDE applauds the issue’s alignment with EU territorial cohesion goals, particularly its role in combating rural depopulation through reliable transport networks in peripheral regions.  
ALDE emphasizes the necessity of preserving transparent public-private partnerships in transport concessions, as exemplified by Spain’s operational framework, to safeguard socially vital services.  
ALDE recognizes the proposal’s potential to advance harmonized market access while urging vigilance in monitoring implementation to prevent unintended erosion of existing functional systems.

GUE_NGL rejects the proposal as it firmly disputes with their commitment to defending public transportation systems against corporate privatization.  
GUE_NGL opposes the issue’s liberalization framework, which overlooks critical aspects of social profitability and territorial cohesion in favor of multinational monopolies.  
GUE_NGL condemns the market-driven approach for failing to address the degradation of labor conditions and public infrastructure highlighted in their arguments.  
GUE_NGL asserts the proposal is inconsistent with their principles by prioritizing private sector entry over state-led strategies for affordable, frequent public transport.  
GUE_NGL warns the regulation’s alignment with Flixbus-style monopolies directly threatens existing public service models proven to ensure universal access.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2017 legislative proposal (COM(2017)0647) concerning transport and tourism, adopting its first-reading stance as outlined in the Committee on Transport and Tourism’s report (A8-0032/2019). It highlighted concerns over compliance with subsidiarity, noting the Irish Houses of the Oireachtas’ reasoned opinion that the proposal encroached on national competencies. The resolution incorporated the European Economic and Social Committee’s 2018 opinion, emphasizing stakeholder consultation. Parliament urged the Commission to resubmit the proposal if substantially amended and directed its President to transmit Parliament’s position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, ensuring alignment with legislative procedures under Article 294 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.

title: Discontinuing seasonal changes of time: REPORT on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council discontinuing seasonal changes of time and repealing Directive 2000/84/EC
background: The EU's seasonal clock changes, harmonized under Directive 2000/84/EC, faced growing criticism over health risks, circadian rhythm disruptions, and economic burdens. A 2018 Commission public consultation revealed 84% support for discontinuing the practice amid concerns about energy inefficacy. The Parliament will discuss ending biannual time adjustments while addressing internal market coordination challenges.

stances.stance:
EFDD fully rejects the issue’s reliance on unverified health and safety claims, contradicting EFDD’s demand for empirical rigor, as Daniela Aiuto emphasized the absence of conclusive scientific evidence linking time changes to negative outcomes.  
EFDD rejects the harmonized EU-wide approach as a violation of subsidiarity, aligning with James Carver’s argument that seasonal adjustments should remain a national prerogative based on geographic and economic needs.  
EFDD highlights the issue’s failure to address critical energy consumption risks, with Daniela Aiuto warning that abandoning summer time could reverse electricity savings, opposing the directive’s economic rationale.  
EFDD criticizes the discretionary power granted to member states to choose permanent time zones, arguing it could fragment cross-border trade and transport—a stance inconsistent with EFDD’s usual advocacy for national sovereignty but reflecting concerns over market coherence.  
EFDD condemns the flawed public consultation process cited in the issue, asserting it lacked transparency and meaningful debate, undermining democratic legitimacy—a core EFDD priority.

GREEN_EFA strongly agrees ending seasonal clock changes, aligning perfectly with their longstanding commitment to public health and circadian rhythm preservation through reduced cardiovascular incidents and accident rates.  
GREEN_EFA entirely promotes the harmonized mediation mechanism to prevent time-zone fragmentation, effectively advancing their priority of cross-border cohesion and internal market stability.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes the directive’s symbolic importance in rejecting wartime-era policies, aligning with Europe’s peace-building legacy by abolishing practices initiated by authoritarian regimes.  
GREEN_EFA proposes amending Article 4 to require member states to submit coordination plans within six months, accelerating implementation while preserving the one-year transition framework.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the issue’s reliance on unprecedented public consultation, urging nations to replicate Croatia’s participatory model to ensure democratic legitimacy in permanent time selection.

resolution: The European Parliament raised support for discontinuing the bi-annual clock change, citing evidence of negative impacts on health (e.g., disrupted circadian rhythms), increased accident rates post-transition, and economic burdens across sectors. It highlighted a 2018 public consultation with 4.6 million responses—84% favoring ending seasonal time shifts—where 99.8% of replies came from citizens. The resolution stressed the need for a harmonized EU-wide approach to preserve the internal market, given the bloc’s three existing time zones (GMT, GMT+1, GMT+2), and urged member states to coordinate decisions on permanent time based on geographical, health, and socioeconomic factors like cross-border trade, transport, and road safety. To facilitate coordination, the Parliament proposed delaying implementation by one year, establishing a mediation network of member state representatives and the Commission to address disputes, and shortening the evaluation period for the directive’s application from five to four years. Member states were encouraged to conduct national consultations to ensure stakeholder and public involvement in choosing between permanent summer or winter time, while avoiding disruptive time-zone fragmentation.

title: Adapting to development in the road transport sector: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) 1071/2009 and Regulation (EC) 1072/2009 with a view to adapting them to developments in the sector
background: The European road transport sector faced evolving operational practices, cross-border complexities, and regulatory gaps in addressing fair competition, driver working conditions, and market access under existing 2009 EU frameworks. The Parliament will discuss amendments to sector-specific regulations to align with contemporary transport realities and enforcement challenges.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA strongly agrees the issue’s prioritization of social protections and safety, aligning perfectly with its commitment to preventing the erosion of workers’ rights in the transport sector.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the emphasis on equal treatment for drivers, effectively advancing fair working conditions as a cornerstone of the EU’s social pillar.  
GREEN_EFA proposes amending Article 3 to explicitly prohibit rest periods in vehicle cabins, ensuring compliance with the Court of Justice’s rulings and safeguarding drivers’ health.  
GREEN_EFA endorses amendments to limit continuous working periods for coach drivers to 10 days, addressing fatigue-related safety risks while maintaining sector flexibility.  
GREEN_EFA urges stricter enforcement of detachment rights to prevent “second-class worker” status, reinforcing the issue’s alignment with fair competition principles.

ECR absolutely conflicts with the issue's wage harmonization efforts, viewing them as discriminatory against Eastern European competitiveness rooted in legitimate cost-of-living differences.  
ECR rejects the imposition of uniform social rules on international transport as market fragmentation disguised as worker protection, inconsistent with single market principles.  
ECR opposes impractical mandates like mandatory hotel stays and truck repatriation, condemning them as economically destructive and environmentally hypocritical.  
ECR challenges claims of unregulated driving hours, asserting existing laws lack enforcement rather than requiring new restrictions that target Eastern operators.  
ECR condemns the proposal as a protectionist tool to bankrupt Eastern businesses under false pretenses of social justice, directly contradicting fair competition principles.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position by adopting a first-reading stance on the Commission’s 2017 legislative proposal (COM(2017)0281) concerning transport policy, grounded in Treaty provisions (Articles 91(1) and 294 TFEU). It emphasized alignment with the Economic and Social Committee’s 2018 opinion and Committee on Employment and Social Affairs’ input, while prioritizing measures to enhance transport sector efficiency, safety, and social protections. The resolution mandated that the Commission must resubmit the proposal to Parliament if it substantially amends or replaces its initial text, ensuring legislative coherence and parliamentary oversight. The Parliament further directed its President to formally transmit its adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing procedural adherence and inter-institutional collaboration.

title: Amending Regulation (EC) No 1071/2009 and Regulation (EC) No 1072/2009 with a view to adapting them to developments in the sector: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) 1071/2009 and Regulation (EC) 1072/2009 with a view to adapting them to developments in the sector
background: Proposed amendments to EU road transport regulations (1071/2009, 1072/2009) address evolving sector dynamics, including cross-border operations, market access requirements, and social rules. The Parliament will discuss regulatory updates to align with contemporary transport practices, operational challenges, and harmonization needs within the single market framework.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA rejects fundamentally the proposed amendments to working time directives as enabling operator exploitation through extended 12-day continuous shifts, directly contradicting CJEU rulings on adequate rest facilities (Article 7 violations).  
GREEN_EFA opposes the cab-rest normalization clause as institutionalizing subhuman conditions, noting Resolution §14’s failure to prohibit mobile sleeping quarters condemned by transport unions.  
GREEN_EFA denounces the diluted posting rules as creating second-class labor statuses, violating Treaty Article 153 principles on equal worker protections across all sectors.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the fatigue-risk escalation through fragmented rest periods, highlighting Keith Taylor’s evidence that 22% of fatal crashes involve sleep-deprived drivers under similar regimes.  
GREEN_EFA refuses any compromise on social dumping mechanisms in Articles 3-4, which Karima Delli exposed as corporate-led deregulation disguised as “sector modernization”.

SD strongly upholds the issue’s alignment with social fairness principles, particularly the reduced two-week reference period for driver rest, which enhances health and safety protections in line with SD’s commitment to eliminating second-class worker status.  
SD proposes strengthening Article 4 to explicitly require weekend rest outside vehicle cabins, ensuring compliance with CJEU rulings and preventing unsafe roadside conditions while maintaining transport efficiency.  
SD approves the integration of EMPL Committee amendments on immediate application of the posted workers directive to prevent wage dumping, urging stricter enforcement mechanisms to close loopholes for non-EU operators.  
SD endorses the TRAN Committee’s balanced approach to cabotage reform but suggests monitoring administrative impacts on Eastern European SMEs to avoid disproportionate market distortions.  
SD emphasizes the need for harmonized per-kilometer pricing across member states to complement “equal pay for equal work” provisions, aligning the issue with fair competition goals while protecting peripheral economies.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2017 transport policy proposal (COM(2017)0281), emphasizing alignment with Treaty objectives under Article 91(1) and incorporating input from the Economic and Social Committee’s January 2018 opinion. It formally adopted its first-reading stance, urging the Commission to re-engage Parliament if proposing significant amendments to the original text, and directed its President to transmit the adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments. The resolution prioritized legislative coherence and procedural accountability while advancing sector-specific measures under the Transport and Tourism Committee’s recommendations, alongside social considerations highlighted by the Employment and Social Affairs Committee.

title: Amending Regulation (EC) No 561/2006 as regards on minimum requirements on maximum daily and weekly driving times, minimum breaks and daily and weekly rest periods and Regulation (EU) 165/2014 as regards positioning by means of tachographs: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 561/2006 as regards on minimum requirements on maximum daily and weekly driving times, minimum breaks and daily and weekly rest periods and Regulation (EU) 165/2014 as regards positioning by means of tachographs
